step1.sentence: My manager had to twist my arm to get me to present at the conference, but I'm glad he did.

step2.story: Sarah didn't want to join the weekend hiking trip, but her friends twisted her arm until she finally agreed. She packed her bag reluctantly, convinced it would be a miserable experience. By the end of the trail, though, she was already planning the next one.

step3.story: Daniel had always avoided public speaking, so when his boss asked him to lead the quarterly presentation, he immediately said no. His colleague spent the next week twisting his arm, reminding him that it would look great for his upcoming promotion review. Daniel finally caved and spent every evening rehearsing in front of his bathroom mirror. The morning of the presentation, his hands were trembling, but he stepped up to the podium anyway. When the applause came at the end, the pride on his face made all the coaxing worthwhile. His boss leaned over and whispered, 'See? Sometimes you just need a little push.'

meaning.literalMeaningKo: 누군가의 팔을 비틀다 — 물리적으로 팔을 꺾는다는 뜻이다.
meaning.realUsageKo: 실제로는 상대방이 원하지 않는 일을 하도록 설득하거나 압박할 때 사용한다. 강제에 가까운 강한 설득을 의미하며, 가벼운 유머나 아이러니한 상황에서도 자주 쓰인다.
meaning.etymologyKo: 팔을 비틀면 상대가 고통스러워 굴복한다는 신체적 강압의 이미지에서 유래했다. 19세기부터 비유적 의미로 영어에서 사용되기 시작했다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 물리적 위협이 아닌 지속적인 설득이나 사회적 압박을 뜻하며, 때로는 '억지로 시키다'는 약간 유머러스한 뉘앙스로도 쓰인다. 완전한 강제보다는 강한 권유에 가깝다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: Nobody twisted her arm — she volunteered for the extra shift all on her own.
meaning.shortExampleKo: 아무도 그녀를 압박하지 않았다 — 그녀는 스스로 추가 근무를 자원했다.
